Award.AwardTitle: Flexible Decision-making in Response to Disruptive Events on Construction Sites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to advance understanding of the improvisational decisions and actions of construction workers in response to workflow disruptions. Disruptions create turbulent conditions that challenge the industry's capabilities for management and control. As a result, flexibility remains critical for the successful response to unexpected incidents on the jobsite. One flexible approach that addresses disruptions is improvisation: the simultaneous generation and execution of a new course of action requiring creativity and skill under tight time constraints. Yet, in spite of more than a decade of research supporting its beneficial uses, skepticism still surrounds the acceptance of improvisation as a flexible way to address disruptions because it evokes images of a lack of structure to the decision making process. Contrary to such beliefs, improvisation is a structured process that involves purposeful human behavior driven by intuition, experience, competence, and context. The proposed investigation will be underpinned by the emerging theory of organizational improvisation, and, accordingly, the PIs will develop and test scientific theory about how, under what conditions, and with what results improvisation can complement detailed planning and plan-following on the jobsite.

If successful, the results of this research will facilitate a better understanding of the interplay between plan-following and improvisation on turbulent construction sites and will allow the research findings to be translated into a theory of improvisational actions in construction. The research has the potential to transform the way craft workers, foremen, and construction managers plan for, accommodate, and manage disruptions on the jobsite. The results of this research will enable a shift in philosophy that supports greater flexibility in decisions and actions. In turn, this will ultimately lead to changes in practice that accept, encourage, and cultivate the use of ?intuition, experience, competence, and context? to overcome daily workflow disruptions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Disruptions occur frequently on constructions sites, and, as a result, construction crew members must often respond to interruptions “in-the-moment.” One flexible approach is to use improvisation: a process of reworking knowledge to produce a novel action in time to meet the requirements of the situation. Improvised decision-making is increasingly being recognized as an important capability that can be used to augment careful task planning, particularly when daily work tasks are disrupted. While studies have documented several factors that influence why and when improvisation is used in work settings, this study specifically focused on identifying the conditions that help or hinder the use of fast improvisational decisions and actions, and how, specifically, fast decisions are made.

 

The investigators discovered that specific types of disruptions on construction sites tend to garner more extensive and faster improvised actions. Specifically, a change in the sequence of the construction work resulted in faster and much more extensive improvised actions. Likewise, interruptions to the workflow tended to produce faster improvised actions. Furthermore, less time pressure and more collaboration among trade workers resulted in more extensive improvised actions.

 

The investigators also discovered that two key decision attributes tended to dominate the improvisational decision-making of construction foremen. First, when work is interrupted, the foreman tended to select replacement tasks that were short in duration (i.e., they could be completed in one day or less) so that they could return to the original task as soon as feasible. Second, when selecting a replacement task, the foreman rapidly determined whether the tools, information, materials, and equipment were available to complete the replacement task. Consequently, nearly all foremen maintained a written or mental backlog of alternative tasks, and when the planned work was disrupted, a significant number of those foremen reviewed the available tools, information, materials, equipment, and time-to-complete an alternative task when rapidly selecting a replacement task (i.e., improvising).

 

This new knowledge is important because the construction industry can use the information to better understand how improvisation occurs on the jobsite and to plan for its use as a complement to detailed planning and plan-following. Given the size of the construction industry, the research contributions (i.e., understanding the conditions that help or hinder effective improvised actions) are expected to directly impact the efficiency of the U.S. construction workforce, and as a result, the economy as a whole. The broader impacts of the research include the following societal benefits: (1) a transformation of the way workers, foremen, and construction managers plan for, accommodate, and manage disruptions on the jobsite; (2) an increase in efficiency of construction workers through a corresponding increase in the effectiveness of improvised actions; and, (3) the transfer of knowledge from the construction industry to other business environments on how employees adjust their actions “in the moment” to adapt to disruptive events in work settings.
